- '''Etiological treatment'''

Avoidance of favouring/triggering factors

- '''Symptomatic treatment'''

2<sup>th</sup> generation anti-H1 antihistamines 1 to 2 tablets/day.

In the event of chronic acute urticaria and/or poor response; 2nd<sup>th</sup> generation anti H1 antihistamines may be increased to 4 tsp/day.


In the event of associated signs of anaphylaxis, treatment should be guided by the symptoms presented;

Ø Parenteral adrenaline in cases of anaphylactic shock or asphyxiant angioedema,

Ø Oxygen therapy if desaturation,

Ø vascular filling if anaphylactic shock,

Ø administration of inhaled beta-2 mimetics in the event of bronchospasm.

question.title: What is the recommended dosage of 2nd generation anti-H1 antihistamines for chronic acute urticaria?
question.description: The dosage of 2nd generation anti-H1 antihistamines for chronic acute urticaria

option_a.title: 1 to 2 tablets/day
option_a.description: A common dosage range for 2nd generation anti-H1 antihistamines

option_b.title: 4 teaspoons/day
option_b.description: A higher dosage range for some patients with chronic acute urticaria

option_c.title: 1 to 4 teaspoons/day
option_c.description: A dosage range that is not typically recommended

option_d.title: 8 tablets/day
option_d.description: A dosage that is not commonly recommended

correct_option.title: 4 tsp/day
correct_option.description: The correct dosage range for some patients with chronic acute urticaria
